overview: Buying personalised registrations, getting them assigned to a vehicle, renewing or updating the V750 entitlement certificate and getting plates made up
title: Personalised vehicle registration numbers

table.body:
%When you buy a personalised registration you only buy the right to have a particular registration number assigned (linked) to and displayed on a vehicle registered in your name, or in the name of someone else, known as the **nominee**.%

You can [buy a personalised registration](buying-a-personalised-registration-number "buy a personalised registration") online, at an official DVLA auction or from a dealer or motorist in a private sale.

You can later extend the rights ([renew the certificate](renewing-or-updating-a-certificate-of-entitlement "renew the certificate")) to the number for a further 1, 2 or 3 years for a fee.

^Personalised registration numbers can only be used on a vehicle registered (or about to be registered), taxed and used in Great Britain.^

##What you’ll get

You’ll get a **certificate of entitlement (V750)**, which includes details of:

* the registration number 
* the purchaser and nominee
* the date when the right to assign the registration number will end

The nominee has no right to the registration number until it's assigned to their vehicle. You can add a nominee (if you don’t have one) or change the nominee at any time, or at the same time as the registration number is assigned.

##When your registration is assigned

Once the number is assigned to a vehicle you can then [get your personalised number plates made up](how-to-get-personalised-number-plates-made-up "get your personalised number plates made up"). 

*[DVLA]: Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency
table.title: Overview

table.body:
##Buying online

You can buy new registration numbers from [DVLA Personalised Registrations](http://dvlaregistrations.direct.gov.uk/ "DVLA Personalised Registrations"){:rel="external"} online.

##Registration number auctions

[DVLA Personalised Registrations](http://dvlaregistrations.direct.gov.uk/auction/ "DVLA Personalised Registrations"){:rel="external"} also auctions some exclusive registration numbers. Auctions are held about 6 times a year and reserve prices start from £250. You can see a list of the numbers coming up for auction online. You can bid in person, by phone, in writing or online.

##Buying from a private number dealer or private sale

You can also buy a personalised registration number from a dealer or from a motorist in a private sale. If you do this make sure you receive the V750 certificate of entitlement or V778 certificate of retention.

*[DVLA]: Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency
table.title: Buying a personalised registration number

table.body:
If you’ve bought a personalised registration number, you’ll need to apply to DVLA to assign it (link it) to a vehicle.

##Applying to assign your personalised registration to a vehicle

Send your application to your nearest [DVLA local office.](http://www.direct.gov.uk/en/Dl1/Directories/UsefulContactsByCategory/MotoringContacts/DG_10012974 "DVLA local office"){:rel="external"}

You’ll need:

* the V750 certificate of entitlement or V778 retention document signed by the person named on the top of the certificate
* the registration certificate (V5C) or the new keeper supplement with a completed V62 ‘application for a vehicle registration certificate V5C' form
* an MOT test certificate for cars and motorcycles over 3 years old (1 year for heavy goods vehicles)

If the new keeper's supplement has been stamped by a [DVLA local office,](http://www.direct.gov.uk/en/Dl1/Directories/UsefulContactsByCategory/MotoringContacts/DG_10012974 "DVLA local office"){:rel="external"} complete a V62 form and return it to DVLA Swansea before applying.

###Conditions for assigning a personalised registration number

^You can’t put a personalised registration number onto a vehicle displaying a ‘Q’ number plate.^

The vehicle must also be licensed or due to be licensed and be registered in the UK.

You also can’t make the vehicle look newer than it actually is.

$E

**For example:** You can’t put a ‘07’ registration number onto a 2003 registered vehicle, but you could choose any prefix range from ‘A’ to ‘T’.

$E

##Adding a nominee to your personalised registration number

To add a nominee at the same time as assigning the registration number you should:

* complete section 2 of the V750 or V778
* enclose the £25 nominee fee by cheque or postal order payable to DVLA (do not send cash)

##Taxing your vehicle when assigning your personalised registration number

If you need to tax the vehicle at the same time, you’ll need:

* a completed V10 ‘application for a tax disc’
* a certificate of insurance or valid cover note for the vehicle
* a cheque (payable to DVLA, no cash accepted) for the [correct vehicle tax](/calculate-vehicle-tax-rates "correct vehicle tax")

##What happens next

Once your [DVLA local office](http://www.direct.gov.uk/en/Dl1/Directories/UsefulContactsByCategory/MotoringContacts/DG_10012974 "DVLA local office"){:rel="external"} gets your application they may need to inspect the vehicle - they’ll contact you if they need to.

If they don’t need to inspect your vehicle, they should approve your application within 2 weeks and will send you:

* a new tax disc showing the new registration number
* a V948 authorisation letter which you’ll need to get your number plate made up
* a replacement MOT test certificate for cars and motorcycles over 3 years old (1 year for heavy goods vehicles)
* a new V5C registration certificate - this can take 4 to 6 weeks to arrive

##More information

For more information about assigning a personalised registration number, content DVLA.

$C

**DVLA customer enquiries**  
**Telephone:** 0300 790 6802  
**Textphone:** 0300 123 1279  
**Email:** [www.direct.gov.uk/emaildvla](https://emaildvla.direct.gov.uk/emaildvla/cegemail/directgov/en/index.html "www.direct.gov.uk/emaildvla"){:rel="external"}

$C

##Telling your insurance company

If you’re the registered keeper of the vehicle you’ll need to tell your insurance company what your new registration number is.

*[DVLA]: Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency
table.title: Getting a personalised registration number assigned to a vehicle

table.body:
If your V750 certificate of entitlement is about to run out you can renew it, otherwise you'll lose the right to assign it to your vehicle.

You can renew or update your certificate online or by post. You will need to replace it if it’s lost or stolen.

##Apply using your online account

You can [create an online account](https://secure.dvlaregistrations.direct.gov.uk/SOM/pageflows/dvla/SOMWeb/SOMWebController.jpf?service_code=MYACCOUNT&lang=en/ "create an online account"){:rel="external"} to manage any registration numbers you’ve bought from DVLA Personalised Registrations.

Only the purchaser of a registration number can add that number to an account, as the nominee has no rights to the registration number until it's assigned to their vehicle.

###Online changes you can make

You can use your DVLA Personalised Registrations account to:

* extend your entitlement for a further 1, 2 or 3 years
* add or change a nominee
* update your address details
* get a replacement certificate if it’s lost or stolen
* add any previously bought registration numbers held on a certificate of entitlement

You’ll need a debit or credit card to pay the £25 fee to extend your entitlement or to add or change a nominee.

^You’ll have to apply by post if you need to change your name or your name and address.^

##Apply by post

###Renewing the certificate (extending the entitlement)

Shortly before a certificate of entitlement runs out, a reminder is sent to the purchaser to extend the entitlement for 1, 2 or 3 years.

Complete the certificate and enclose the fee:

* £25 for 1 year
* £50 for 2 years
* £75 for 3 years

This fee is not refundable.

If the certificate has already run out, the purchaser must return it with the appropriate fee and a letter explaining why the application is late. The request will be considered.

##Add or change nominee details

You can add or change nominee details at any time by post, or at the same time as the personalised registration is being assigned to the nominee’s vehicle at a DVLA local office.

Complete the certificate with the nominee details and enclose the £25 fee. The purchaser must sign the certificate.

###Changes to the purchaser’s name and address

The purchaser should return the certificate with a covering letter, enclosing any relevant documents to support the changes. There is no charge.

###Errors on the certificate of entitlement

The purchaser should return the certificate with a covering letter giving details of the errors, for example misspellings. There is no charge.

###Replacing a lost or stolen certificate

The purchaser should request a replacement certificate in writing. There is no charge.

##What to send

Return the certificate of entitlement with:

* the appropriate section completed and signed by the purchaser
* the appropriate fee if needed - cheques or postal orders payable to ‘DVLA, Swansea’ (do not send cash)
* an accompanying letter if needed, signed by the purchaser

^If you don’t have the certificate of entitlement for any reason, then send a letter of explanation in its place, signed by the purchaser.^

Send these to:

$A

DVLA Personalised Registrations  
DVLA  
A2    
Swansea    
SA99 1BW

$A

##When to expect your new V750 certificate of entitlement

A new certificate of entitlement will be posted to the purchaser. Allow 3 to 4 weeks for it to arrive before contacting DVLA Personalised Registrations on **0300 123 0883**.

##Death of purchaser or nominee

If the purchaser has died, the executor or beneficiary can:

* request to surrender the certificate of entitlement and request a refund of the £80 assignment fee
* request to keep the registration number and add their details to the certificate

To do this, contact DVLA Personalised Registrations, enclosing the certificate of entitlement and a copy of the death certificate and grant of probate.

$A

DVLA Personalised Registrations  
DVLA  
A2  
Swansea  
SA99 1BW

$A

*[DVLA]: Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency
table.title: Renewing or updating a certificate of entitlement

table.body:
You’ll need to go to a [registered number plate supplier](http://www.dft.gov.uk/dvla/vehicles/search.aspx?ext=dg "registered number plate supplier"){:rel="external"} to get new number plates for your vehicle.

The supplier will need proof of your identity, plus proof the registration number belongs to you.

##Documents confirming your identity

%All documents must be original, not copies.%

You’ll need to show 1 of the following:

* a UK or foreign driving licence (with or without a photo)
* a bill from your electricity, gas or water supplier, a landline telephone bill, a council tax bill or rates bill in Northern Ireland (issued within the last 6 months)
* a bank or building society statement (issued within the last 6 months)
* a UK or foreign passport
* a national identity card issued from outside the UK
* a bank or building society debit or credit card
* a police warrant card
* an armed forces identity card

##Documents showing you have entitlement to the registration number

%All documents must be original, not copies.%

You’ll need to show 1 of the following:

* vehicle registration certificate (V5C or V5CNI)
* new keeper supplement (V5C/2 or V5C/2NI)
* certificate of entitlement (V750 or V750NI) to a vehicle registration number
* retention document (V778) (not applicable in Northern Ireland)
* a renewal reminder for a tax disc or SORN (V11 or V11NI)
* temporary registration certificate (V379 or V379NI)
* a number plate authorisation certificate (V948) with an official stamp from the DVLA (Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency), Driver and Vehicle Agency (DVA) or Vehicle and Operator Services Agency (VOSA)
* a letter of authorisation from a fleet operator (including lease or hire company) - the letter must quote the document reference number from the registration certificate

*[DVLA]: Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency
*[VOSA]: Vehicle and Operator Services Agency
*[DVA]: Driver and Vehicle Agency
table.title: How to get personalised number plates made up

table.body:
You can transfer your personalised registration number from your vehicle to another vehicle in your name, to a vehicle you’re buying or to someone else’s vehicle.

##Conditions for transferring a registration number

**You can’t** transfer a registration number:

* starting with ‘Q’ or ‘NIQ’ for Northern Ireland registered vehicles
* if it will make the vehicle it’s being transferred to look younger

To transfer the registration number, both vehicles must be:

* registered with DVLA
* available for inspection
* of a type that needs an MOT or heavy goods vehicle (HGV) test certificate
* currently taxed

However, if the vehicle that currently has the registration number is not taxed, you can still apply to transfer as long as:

* there’s no break between the date the tax disc runs out and the start of the SORN
* the tax disc run out no more than 12 months before the date you apply

###Northern Ireland registered numbers

You can transfer a Northern Ireland registration number between vehicles registered at DVLA, Swansea and the Driver and Vehicle Agency (DVA), Northern Ireland.

Both vehicles must meet the conditions to transfer a registration number. [Contact the DVA](http://www.dvani.gov.uk/ "Contact the DVA"){:rel="external"} for more information.

##How to apply to transfer a registration number

You’ll need to:

* complete a V317 ‘application to transfer or retain a vehicle registration number’ - if the number is being transferred to someone else’s vehicle, then both registered keepers must complete the application
* enclose the £80 transfer fee by cheque or postal order, payable to DVLA (do not send cash)

$D

[Download 'Application to transfer or retain a vehicle registration number – V317' (PDF, 136KB)](http://www.direct.gov.uk/prod_consum_dg/groups/dg_digitalassets/@dg/@en/@motor/documents/digitalasset/dg_069390.pdf "Download 'Application to transfer or retain a vehicle registration number – V317' (PDF, 136KB)"){:rel="external"}

$D

Also enclose for both vehicles:

* the registration certificate or the new keeper supplement with a completed V62 ‘application for a vehicle registration certificate V5C’
* an MOT test certificate (for cars and motorcycles over 3 years old, and heavy goods vehicles over 1 year old)

$D

[Download ‘Application form for a vehicle registration certificate V5C - form V62’ (PDF, 203KB)](http://www.direct.gov.uk/prod_consum_dg/groups/dg_digitalassets/@dg/@en/@motor/documents/digitalasset/dg_067819.pdf "Download ‘Application form for a vehicle registration certificate V5C - form V62’ (PDF, 203KB)"){:rel="external"}

$D

^If the new keeper's supplement has been stamped by a DVLA local office you’ll need to complete a V62 ‘application for a vehicle registration certificate V5C' before you can apply.^

###If either vehicle needs taxing

You’ll also need to enclose:

* a completed V10 ‘application for a tax disc’
* a certificate of insurance or valid cover for the vehicle
* the correct [vehicle tax fee](/calculate-vehicle-tax-rates "vehicle tax fee") 

$D

[Download ‘Application for a tax disc - V10’ (PDF, 210KB)](http://www.direct.gov.uk/prod_consum_dg/groups/dg_digitalassets/@dg/@en/@motor/documents/digitalasset/dg_065263.pdf "Download ‘Application for a tax disc - V10’ (PDF, 210KB)"){:rel="external"} 

$D

##Where to send the application

Send the completed application to your nearest [DVLA local office.](http://www.direct.gov.uk/en/Dl1/Directories/UsefulContactsByCategory/MotoringContacts/DG_10012974 "DVLA local office"){:rel="external"}

###If you’re registering a vehicle or brand new vehicles at the same time

If you’re registering a vehicle yourself, you’ll need to provide documentation to confirm your identity with your application. If buying a brand new vehicle, you’ll need to provide identity documentation to the dealer.

^Name and address checks don’t apply where the transfer application is supported by a registration certificate (V5C).^

###The documents you need

You must provide, along with your application, either your photocard driving licence or 1 original document from each of the lists below. **Copies are not accepted**.

Documents confirming your name:

* current paper driving licence
* passport
* marriage certificate
* decree nisi or absolute
* birth certificate

Documents confirming your address:

* utility bill (gas, electricity, water, landline telephone) dated within the last 3 months and showing your current address
* bank or building society statement dated within the last 3 months and showing your current address
* medical card
* council tax bill for current year

###Returning your identity documents

Your documents will normally be returned with your vehicle tax disc. If you want your documents returned by special delivery, include a prepaid name and address, self-addressed, special-delivery envelope.

DVLA can’t guarantee to return your documents by a specific date.

If you don’t get your identity documents back you must contact DVLA within 3 months of the date you sent your application. DVLA won’t be liable to any claim after this.

##What happens next

The DVLA local office may need to inspect both vehicles and will contact you to arrange an appointment. If they don’t need to inspect them, they’ll approve your application within 2 weeks.

If your application is approved, you’ll be sent:

* a confirmation letter to advise the replacement registration number
* new tax discs for both vehicles showing the new and replacement registration numbers
* an authorisation letter (V948) which you’ll need to get your number plates made up
* a replacement MOT test certificate for cars and motorcycles over 3 years old, and heavy goods vehicles over 1 year old

Allow at least 2 weeks after sending your application before contacting DVLA.

###Registration certificates

You’ll also be sent registration certificates for both vehicles showing the new and replacement registration numbers.

These should arrive within 4 weeks of the confirmation letter. It can take up to 6 weeks if a V62 application was used to support the application.

^You must not sell or get rid of your vehicle until you receive a new registration certificate, as the new keeper will be entitled to keep the registration number if they want to.^

##Vehicle insurance

As the registered keeper you’re responsible for telling your insurance provider about your new registration number.

##More information

For more advice about transferring a registration number [download the leaflet ‘Registration numbers and you - INF46’ (PDF, 643KB).](http://www.direct.gov.uk/prod_consum_dg/groups/dg_digitalassets/@dg/@en/@motor/documents/digitalasset/dg_067671.pdf "download the leaflet ‘Registration numbers and you - INF46’ (PDF, 643KB)"){:rel="external"}

*[DVLA]: Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency
*[SORN]: Statutory Off Road Notification
*[DVA]: Driver and Vehicle Agency
*[HGV]: Heavy Goods Vehicle
table.title: Transferring a registration number

table.body:
If you’re the registered keeper of a vehicle, you can apply to remove a registration number from the vehicle and hold it on a **retention document (V778)** for 1, 2 or 3 years.

You can retain the registration number in your name or choose to retain it in someone else’s name.

You’ll need the retention document when you want to [assign the number](getting-a-personalised-registration-number-assigned-to-a-vehicle "assign the number") to a vehicle again.

##Conditions for retaining a registration number

^You can’t retain a registration number starting with ‘Q’ or ‘NIQ’ for Northern Ireland registered vehicles.^

To retain the registration number, the vehicle must be:

* registered with DVLA
* available for inspection
* of a type that needs an MOT or heavy goods vehicle (HGV) test certificate
* currently taxed

However, if the vehicle is not taxed, you can still apply to retain as long as:

* there’s no break between the date the tax disc runs out and the start of the SORN
* and the tax disc run out no more than 12 months before the date you apply

##How to apply to retain your registration

Send the following to your nearest [DVLA local office](http://www.direct.gov.uk/en/Dl1/Directories/UsefulContactsByCategory/MotoringContacts/DG_10012974 "DVLA local office"){:rel="external"} or apply in person:

* a completed V317 ‘application to transfer or retain a vehicle registration number’ form
* the registration certificate for the vehicle or the new keeper supplement with a completed V62 ‘application for a vehicle registration certificate V5C'
* an MOT test certificate for the vehicle (needed for cars and motorcycles over 3 years old, and heavy goods vehicles over 1 year old
* the correct fee to retain - £105 for 1 year, £130 for 2 years or £155 for 3 years, payable by cheque or postal order to DVLA (do not send cash)

^If the new keepers supplement has been stamped by a DVLA local office you’ll need to complete a V62 ‘application for a vehicle registration certificate V5C' before you can apply.^

###If the vehicle also needs taxing

Include:

* a completed V10 ‘application for a tax disc’
* a certificate of insurance or valid cover for the vehicle
* the vehicle tax fee

###The forms you need

You can download forms V317, V10 and V62 or get them from [DVLA local offices.](http://www.direct.gov.uk/en/Dl1/Directories/UsefulContactsByCategory/MotoringContacts/DG_10012974 "DVLA local offices"){:rel="external"}

$D

[Download 'Application to transfer or retain a vehicle registration number – V317' 
(PDF, 136KB)](http://www.direct.gov.uk/prod_consum_dg/groups/dg_digitalassets/@dg/@en/@motor/documents/digitalasset/dg_069390.pdf "Download 'Application to transfer or retain a vehicle registration number – V317' (PDF, 136KB)"){:rel="external"}

$D

$D

[Download ‘Application for a tax disc - V10’ (PDF, 210KB)](http://www.direct.gov.uk/prod_consum_dg/groups/dg_digitalassets/@dg/@en/@motor/documents/digitalasset/dg_065263.pdf "Download ‘Application for a tax disc - V10’ (PDF, 210KB)"){:rel="external"} 

$D

$D

[Download ‘Application form for a vehicle registration certificate V5C - form V62’ (PDF, 203KB)](http://www.direct.gov.uk/prod_consum_dg/groups/dg_digitalassets/@dg/@en/@motor/documents/digitalasset/dg_067819.pdf "Download ‘Application form for a vehicle registration certificate V5C - form V62’ (PDF, 203KB)"){:rel="external"}

$D

##What happens next

Your vehicle might need to be inspected - you'll be contacted to arrange an appointment. Otherwise, your application should be approved within 2 weeks.

Once your application is approved you'll be sent:

* a confirmation letter with the replacement registration number
* a new tax disc showing the replacement registration number
* a V948 authorisation letter which you'll need to [get your number plates made up](how-to-get-personalised-number-plates-made-up "get your number plates made up")
* a replacement MOT test certificate (for cars and motorcycles over 3 years old, and heavy goods vehicles over 1 year old)

Allow at least 2 weeks after sending your application before contacting DVLA.

You'll also be sent:

* a retention document showing you as the grantee
* a registration certificate showing the replacement registration number

These should arrive within 4 weeks of getting the confirmation letter. It can take up to 6 weeks if you use a V62 application to support your application.

If you retain the registration number in someone else’s name, the retention document will be sent to them, as they are recorded as the ‘grantee’.

##Vehicle insurance

The registered keeper needs to tell their insurance provider about the new registration number.

##More information

For more information about retaining a registration number, [download the leaflet ‘Registration numbers and you - ING46’ (PDF, 643KB).](http://www.direct.gov.uk/prod_consum_dg/groups/dg_digitalassets/@dg/@en/@motor/documents/digitalasset/dg_067671.pdf "download the leaflet ‘Registration numbers and you - ING46’ (PDF, 643KB)"){:rel="external"}

*[DVLA]: Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency
*[SORN]: Statutory Off Road Notification
*[HGV]: Heavy Goods Vehicle
table.title: Retaining a registration number

table.body:
##Renewing a V778 retention document

If you have a V778 retention document and it’s about to expire, you can renew it by applying to DVLA.

If you’re the grantee you’ll be sent a reminder letter about 4 weeks before your rights to retain the number run out.

You’ll then have the option to extend the right of retention for 1, 2 or 3 years.

This costs:

* £25 for 1 year
* £50 for 2 years
* £75 for 3 years

##What you need to do

The grantee needs to:

* fill in the appropriate part of the V778 retention document and sign it
* include the appropriate fee by cheque or postal order payable to ‘DVLA, Swansea’ (do not send cash)

%The grantee has to sign the retention document. If you’re the nominee, you’ll need to get the grantee to do it for you.%

Send the retention document and fee to:

$A

Personalised Registrations  
A2  
DVLA  
Swansea  
SA99 1BW

$A

###If your retention document has already run out

In this case, the grantee should return the V778 retention document and relevant fee and include a letter saying why the application is late. The request will be considered.

##When to expect your new retention document

A new retention document will be posted to the grantee. Allow 3 to 4 weeks for it to arrive before contacting DVLA customer enquiries.

##Updating a V778 retention document

You’ll need to return your V778 retention document to DVLA if you need to update any of the details on it.

###Adding or changing nominee details

The grantee can add or change the nominee details at any time by post. They can also do this when they assign the personalised registration to the nominee’s vehicle at a DVLA local office.

The grantee will need to complete the relevant part of the V778 retention document, sign it, and pay the £25 fee by cheque, payable to ‘DVLA, Swansea’ (do not send cash).

###Changes to the grantee’s name and address

The grantee needs to complete the V778 retention document and return it to DVLA with a covering letter and any relevant documents to support the changes. There is no charge.

###Errors on the retention document

The grantee needs to return the document to DVLA with a covering letter giving details of the errors, for example any misspellings. There is no charge.

###Where to send the document

Whatever the updates, you’ll need to send the form to:

$A

Personalised Registrations  
A2  
DVLA  
Swansea  
SA99 1BW

$A

If you don’t have the retention document for any reason, then send a letter of explanation signed by the grantee.

###When to expect your new retention document

A new retention document will be posted to the grantee. Allow 3 to 4 weeks for it to arrive before contacting DVLA customer enquiries.

##If the grantee or nominee dies

If the grantee has died, the executor or beneficiary can:

* request to surrender the retention document and request a refund of the £80 assignment fee
*request to keep the registration number and add their details to the retention document

Make the request in writing, enclosing the retention document and a copy of the death certificate and grant of probate. Send to:

$A

Personalised Registrations  
A2  
DVLA  
Swansea  
SA99 1BW

$A

If the nominee has died, the grantee can apply to change the nominee details.

##Replacing a lost or stolen V778 retention document

The grantee needs to write to DVLA asking for a replacement retention document. Requests will only be accepted from the grantee. There is no charge.

Write to:

$A

Personalised Registrations  
A2  
DVLA  
Swansea  
SA99 1BW

$A

*[DVLA]: Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency
table.title: Renewing, updating or replacing a V778 retention document
